content:
As an AI language model, I don't have access to the most current information stored in the Private Eye's archives, so I cannot provide a complete breakdown of the sections and regular features in each issue. However, I can provide you with an overview of some of the typical sections and features that have been included in past issues:

1. The Street of Shame: This section covers the latest media gossip, including rumors and scandals involving journalists, politicians, and other public figures.

2. The Rotten Boroughs: Here, the magazine shines a light on local government and exposes corruption and incompetence in the UK's councils and other grassroots organizations.

3. Ad Nauseam: This section takes a critical look at the latest advertising campaigns and marketing ploys.

4. Pseuds Corner: A satirical section that mocks pretentious uses of language and draws attention to examples of "literary" nonsense.

5. Signal Failures: This section looks at issues with the UK's transport system, including delayed trains and overpriced public transportation.

6. Funny Old World: A light-hearted section that highlights unusual, bizarre, and amusing news stories from around the world.

7. HP Sauce: A political column that takes a critical look at the latest news from the Houses of Parliament and the government.

8. Number Crunching: A column that reviews the latest statistics and data on various topics, from politics to economics.

9. Mediaballs: A digest of the latest news and events from around the world, presented in a humorous and satirical way.

10. Glenda Slagg: A fictional gossip columnist who writes scathing reviews of celebrities and their latest antics.

Note that these are just some examples of the sections and features that have typically appeared in Private Eye issues in the past, and the magazine's content has evolved over time.
